articles.title: Call for free bus passes to help under-22s into work
articles.summary: A pilot scheme for free travel at any time of day would help them get to work and education, a report says.
articles.content:
Call for free bus passes to help under-22s into work

5 hours ago Share Save Emer Moreau & Charlotte Edwards Business reporter, BBC News Share Save

Getty Images

Under-22s in England should be given free bus passes to help them get into work and education, according to a report by MPs. The number of bus journeys taken in England has dropped in recent years, while fares have risen faster than inflation, it said. This was a barrier to opportunity and growth in some areas, MPs found, recommending a pilot scheme of free bus travel at any time of day for under-22s. The Department for Transport said it was providing "£1bn in multi-year funding to improve the reliability and frequency of bus services across the country".

Since January 2022, everyone in Scotland aged between five and 22 has been entitled to free bus travel. In England, the number of bus passenger journeys had dropped from 4.6 billion in 2009 to 3.6 billion in 2024, the report by the Transport Committee said. Some smaller towns and rural areas have no bus services at all, or buses that run so infrequently that "they do not meaningfully add to people's transport options", it said. A 2019 study found that some 57% of jobseekers lived in areas where they could not reach a centre of employment within 45 minutes by bus. "High bus fares and limited local provision can severely restrict young people's access to education, employment, and other opportunities," the report said.

'We rely on public transport'

Alex Mustafa

Alex Mustafa, 19, says she uses the bus all the time as she can't drive due to health and financial reasons and would benefit from a free bus pass. "It would also help poorer young people like myself who rely on public transport to better plan for social connections without needing to worry about bus cost on top of how expensive it is to go out as it is," she said. Alex says she has been left waiting for a bus for over an hour before and has been late to work and missed social events due to cancelled buses. "It's very difficult to live life according to plan when you have to plan around an unreliable schedule. Trains are sometimes better, but they also come with a higher cost and they're more limiting with location," she said.

Roman Dibden, chief executive of youth charity Rise Up, said it sees young people turn down job interviews and training all the time because they can't afford the bus fare. "Free bus passes for under-22s would remove a huge barrier, opening up access to jobs, apprenticeships, and training - especially in communities where opportunity isn't on your doorstep."

'Support people who struggle costs-wise'

Dylan Lewis-Creser

Dylan Lewis-Creser, 21, is a student in town planning and also stood as a Green Party candidate for Walkley Ward in the local elections in May 2024. They told the BBC they use the bus quite a lot to travel around Sheffield as driving is too expensive. "A free bus pass would mean I could get to and from university and work without paying £10 a week, which adds up significantly as a student on a low budget," they said. "That cost is amplified when considering changing buses to get to other job opportunities and elsewhere, like hospitals." Dylan thinks there needs to be more discussion around "making transport accessible, affordable and reliable." "Part of that would be supporting people who often struggle costs-wise to do that, such as young people," they said. "We've seen how it's boosted young people using buses in Scotland, and it only makes sense to extend that policy."

Bus passengers spend £39.1 billion in local businesses every year, according to research from KPMG. But experts told the Transport Committee that the bus sector's contribution to the economy declined by around £8.9 billion between 2011 and 2023. The report said: "The current deregulated nature of the bus sector can encourage commercial operators to "deprioritise" less profitable routes, often leaving vulnerable communities without a service."

'Social exclusion'

The committee heard that older people were particularly deterred from using the bus if they felt unsafe at bus stops. The report recommended improvements to bus stops and shelters such as screen showing real-time information. Jane Bishop is the chief executive of North Norfolk Community Transport, a charity that provides low-cost dial-a-ride services in the local area. She says for some people bus services mean the difference between being able to stay in their homes or having to move into assisted living.

Jane Bishop North Norfolk Community Transport helps people get around if they can't drive

"Most of our passengers are older people, but not all," she told the BBC. "A lot of people, we're the only people they see every week." "They become friends with the other people on their route so it's a great tool for combatting loneliness," Ms Bishop said. But, she added, "it's a lottery whether there is a community transport in your area".

Fare cap

The cap on bus fares outside London was increased to £3 last year. The committee said fare caps were most beneficial to people in rural areas, as they tended to take longer journeys or had to use multiple buses for one trip. But the report was critical of the short-term nature of funding for bus services, saying it has "hampered local authorities' ability to improve services". "Five-year settlements in other transport sectors like rail and the strategic road network have enabled greater certainty and promoted strategic planning," it said. "Bus services, the most widely used form of public transport, require a similar commitment."

Bus services are devolved in England, meaning they are the responsibility of local authorities. Individual councils could choose to offer concessions to under-22s. The Local Government Association (LGA) welcomed the committee's recommendation to end "stop-start funding" for buses. A spokesperson said: "Bus services provide an essential mode of public transport in local communities, relied upon by millions of people. "More work is needed to attract them back onto buses to ensure services are sustainable for our communities. Stop-start funding risks losing passengers, with patronage difficult to recover if and when money is found."

Steff Aquarone, a Liberal Democrat MP who sits on the Transport Committee, said the report shows the need for "a different model for rural public transport". He said local councils cannot heavily subsidise bus fares as in other countries, but "if you put buses on at the time people want to travel, going to places they want to go, people will use them".

articles.personality_title: MPs propose free bus passes for under-22s to improve access to work and education
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Bus travel in England has dropped in recent years while bus fares have increased faster than the cost of living. This makes it harder for young people, especially under 22, to get to jobs or education. In Scotland, free bus travel has been available for people aged 5 to 22 since 2022.

**What happened**
A group of members of parliament (MPs) in England suggested a pilot program to give free bus passes to everyone under 22. This would let them travel anytime without paying. The report says this would help young people reach work, training, and school more easily. They also pointed out that some towns and rural areas have very few or no bus services, making travel difficult.

**Impact**
The proposal aims to remove a big barrier for young people who cannot afford bus fares. For example, a 19-year-old named Alex said she often misses work or social events because buses are unreliable and expensive. A youth charity leader explained that free bus travel could help young people accept job interviews or training they otherwise would skip. The report also highlights how better bus services support local businesses and reduce social isolation, especially for older people.

**What's next step**
The government’s Department for Transport is currently funding improvements in bus services, but no decision has been made yet about free passes for under-22s in England. Local councils can offer discounts but need more stable funding to improve and keep bus routes running. The MPs recommend longer-term funding plans and better bus schedules to meet the needs of young people.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Giving free bus passes to under-22s in England could help more young people get to work and education by making bus travel affordable and reliable.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les députés proposent des passes de bus gratuits pour les moins de 22 ans afin de faciliter l'accès au travail et à l'éducation
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le nombre de trajets en bus en Angleterre a diminué ces dernières années tandis que le prix des billets a augmenté plus vite que le coût de la vie. Cela rend plus difficile pour les jeunes, surtout ceux de moins de 22 ans, d'accéder aux emplois ou à l'éducation. En Écosse, les trajets en bus sont gratuits pour les personnes âgées de 5 à 22 ans depuis 2022.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Un groupe de députés en Angleterre a suggéré un programme pilote pour offrir des passes de bus gratuits à tous les moins de 22 ans. Cela leur permettrait de voyager à tout moment sans payer. Le rapport explique que cela aiderait les jeunes à accéder plus facilement au travail, à la formation et à l'école. Ils ont aussi souligné que certaines villes petites et zones rurales ont peu ou pas de services de bus, rendant les déplacements difficiles.

**Impact**
La proposition vise à supprimer un obstacle important pour les jeunes qui ne peuvent pas payer le bus. Par exemple, une jeune de 19 ans, Alex, a dit qu'elle rate souvent le travail ou des sorties à cause des bus peu fiables et coûteux. Un responsable d'une association pour la jeunesse a expliqué que la gratuité des bus pourrait aider les jeunes à accepter des entretiens d'embauche ou des formations qu'ils oublieraient autrement. Le rapport souligne aussi comment de meilleurs services de bus soutiennent les commerces locaux et réduisent l'isolement social, surtout chez les personnes âgées.

**Prochaine étape**
Le ministère des Transports finance actuellement des améliorations des services de bus, mais aucune décision n'a encore été prise sur les passes gratuits pour les moins de 22 ans en Angleterre. Les conseils locaux peuvent offrir des réductions, mais ils ont besoin d'un financement plus stable pour améliorer et maintenir les lignes de bus. Les députés recommandent des plans de financement à long terme et des horaires de bus mieux adaptés aux besoins des jeunes.

**Phrase clé**
Offrir des passes de bus gratuits aux moins de 22 ans en Angleterre pourrait aider plus de jeunes à accéder au travail et à l'éducation en rendant le bus abordable et fiable.
articles.personality_title_es: Diputados proponen pases de autobús gratuitos para menores de 22 años para facilitar el acceso al trabajo y la educación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los viajes en autobús en Inglaterra han disminuido en los últimos años, mientras que las tarifas han subido más rápido que el costo de vida. Esto dificulta que los jóvenes, especialmente los menores de 22 años, lleguen a trabajos o educación. En Escocia, desde 2022, las personas de 5 a 22 años pueden viajar gratis en autobús.

**Qué pasó**
Un grupo de diputados en Inglaterra propuso un programa piloto para dar pases de autobús gratuitos a todos los menores de 22 años. Esto les permitiría viajar en cualquier momento sin pagar. El informe dice que esto ayudaría a los jóvenes a llegar más fácilmente a trabajos, formación y escuelas. También señalaron que algunos pueblos y áreas rurales tienen pocos o ningún servicio de autobús, lo que dificulta el transporte.

**Impacto**
La propuesta busca eliminar una gran barrera para los jóvenes que no pueden pagar el autobús. Por ejemplo, una joven de 19 años llamada Alex dijo que a menudo llega tarde al trabajo o pierde eventos sociales porque los autobuses son caros e irregulares. Un líder de una organización juvenil explicó que el viaje gratuito podría ayudar a los jóvenes a aceptar entrevistas de trabajo o formación que de otra forma rechazarían. El informe también destaca cómo mejores servicios de autobús apoyan a los negocios locales y reducen el aislamiento social, especialmente en personas mayores.

**Próximo paso**
El Departamento de Transporte está financiando mejoras en los servicios de autobús, pero aún no se ha decidido sobre pases gratuitos para menores de 22 años en Inglaterra. Los consejos locales pueden ofrecer descuentos, pero necesitan fondos más estables para mejorar y mantener las rutas de autobús. Los diputados recomiendan planes de financiamiento a largo plazo y horarios de autobús que se ajusten a las necesidades de los jóvenes.

**Frase clave**
Dar pases de autobús gratuitos a los menores de 22 años en Inglaterra podría ayudar a más jóvenes a acceder al trabajo y la educación al hacer que viajar en autobús sea más accesible y confiable.
